content.description:
The biggest drainage on the North Face of the South Bluff. You won't need an ice axe or crampons, but they'll make it more enjoyable and help create the illusion that you're actually in a real couloir. There are some ice steps, but truthfully you'll have a harder time stepping over downed trees than negotiating the ice. 

  This gully is a beautiful part of the park and I highly recommend a visit - the "climbing" leaves a little to be desired, but the environment and solitude are everything anyone can ask for in this part of the world.
content.location:
This route is the second major gully you will encounter on your right after the berm on your left subsides as you're walking down the tracks from the south shore parking lot. 

  Manley Creek Gulley is the eastern gulley marked in this map.

content.description: The highlight here is the bouldering potential as one ascends this drainage. Follow the gulley to the top for a good look at it all. There wasn't much (if any) ice to speak of when I did this thing in early season, but there might be as the season goes on.
content.protection: An ice axe makes this more comfortable.
content.location: This route is the first major gully you will encounter on your right after the berm on your left subsides as you're walking down the tracks from the south shore parking lot.

content.description:
If you follow the railroad tracks along the north side of the South bluff you will encounter several gully systems, and they might be of interest to you for several reasons. 

  1st - It's an obscure part of the park where you're unlikely to encounter other people. 

  2nd - If you're an alpine climber, then you can almost pretend you're in an alpine environment. 

  3rd - Some of these gullies have decent bouldering potential. 

  Originally I debated whether to bother posting this area, but I figured it might entice those looking for this kind of experience or be information to save some time for those who might see this on a topographic map and be searching for something else (like real climbing).
